The lowest standard is “prima facie evidence,” which requires merely indicative or plausible proof. An intermediate standard is “preponderance of probability,” under which the existence of the fact to be proved must be more likely than not, or, in other words, that it is reasonably probable (Green, 2009). Whereas common law jurisdictions apply all three standards of proof depending on the situation, civil law jurisdiction tend to limit the standard of proof to a single general rule: the judge must be “convinced” that a disputed fact is true (Dederer and Singer, 2019).” (Greiman, 2021, p. 105)

“Assuming a State’s technical and legal analysis is capable of attributing an attack, what are the options available to a victim nation after an attack? Cyber-attacks in the United States and around the globe have demonstrated various responses by nation states. The most common form of response is through economic punishment or denial of benefits offered by international treaties or conventions. In cases where the evidence is clear as to the attacker it might justify retaliation through counter measures. In the case of a cyber war the response may be a declaration of war against the nation state. According to the Council on Foreign Relations Cyber Operations Tracker, since 2005, thirty-four countries are suspected of sponsoring cyber operations. China, Russia, Iran, and North Korea sponsored 77 percent of all suspected operations. In 2019, there were a total of seventy-six operations, most being acts of espionage (CFR, 2020). Recent attacks shown in table 1 highlight this reality. In a recent study of private sector attribution of cyber incidents, sponsored by the Office of the Secretary of Defense and the RAND National Defense Research Institute, the most commonly stated motive for U.S. government attribution was to promote deterrence in cyberspace. Participants also noted that public attribution may help build international consensus on what constitutes irresponsible or inappropriate behavior in cyberspace (Romanosky and Boudreaux, 2020).” (Greiman, 2021, p. 104)

“Cyber attribution is a topic covered quite extensively in the literature however, the legal requirements of attribution are clearly lacking due to the failure of a universal consensus on the laws, regulations and standards that are applicable when attributing a cyber-attack to a state-sponsored entity. As shown in figure 1, this paper explores the relationship between the law of attribution, the evidence required to prove attribution, and the responses that nation states have chosen when faced with decisions that require careful evaluation of the interests faced by the victim nation including economic, social, political, and national security interests. The research comprises a review and comparative analysis of the international law governing attribution, the applicable rules of evidence, and the analysis of recent literature including government and private sector studies that analyze state responses to cyber-attacks.” (Greiman, 2021, p. 103)

“As highlighted in Delbert Tran’s (2018) overview of the law of attribution, before developing rules for attribution it is important to note the distinctions in adversarial v. inquisitorial legal systems which govern most of the legal world. The features of adversarial and inquisitorial systems include common characteristics such as burdens of proof and persuasion, state responsibility doctrines, and rules governing evidentiary production. Though the features are similar they can be administered in different ways. The adversarial system assumes that the best way to get to the truth of a matter is through a competitive process to determine the facts and application of the law accurately. The inquisitorial system associated with civil law legal systems, is characterized by extensive pre-trial investigation and interrogations with the objective to avoid bringing an innocent person to trial. The inquisitorial process can be described as an official inquiry to ascertain the truth, whereas the adversarial system uses a competitive process between prosecution and defence to determine the facts. (Reichel, 2018). For example, in the United States, the burden of production is a minimal burden to produce at least enough evidence for the trier of fact to consider a disputed claim. After litigants have met the burden of production, they have the burden of persuasion: that enough evidence has been presented to persuade the trier of fact that their side is correct.” (Greiman, 2021, p. 105)

“Following a cyber-attack, States have to deal with the challenge of attribution defined as “identifying the agent responsible for the action” (Clark and Landau, 2011). Cyber attribution is the process by which evidence of a malicious cyber activity is collected, analyzed, and identified with the attacker (Rid and Buchanan, 2015). This is not an easy task due to technological challenges and the ability to hide behind the anonymity of other actors and agents (Tallin 2.0, 2017). Though identifying the machines has become much easier for sophisticated cyber states, identifying the persons, organization, or states that are legally responsible for the cyberattack remains the ultimate challenge (Carlin, 2016). Significant technological strides in attributing cyber events in the last decade have made the task “more nuanced, more common, and more political than has typically been acknowledged” (Rid and Buchanan, 2015). The political aspect includes assessing what is at stake in making the attribution judgment, starting with the damage incurred, whether physical, financial, or reputational (Rid and Buchanan, p. 7). As such, attribution is often expressed in degrees of certainty, and it requires input from a range of actors and sources, including technical forensics, human intelligence, signals intelligence, history, and diplomatic relations (Banks, 2019).” (Greiman, 2021, p. 102)

“Invariably, one of the first responses after a cyber-attack is: Who did it and how do we know? In legal terminology the legal process for charging someone with a wrongful act is known as burden of proof. In the attribution world this concept is little discussed in the context of a cyber-attack. The law of attribution conjures up numerous questions on the procedural side as even if the substantive law is clear the procedural rules may be ridden with twists and turns that make it difficult to prove your case. In international disputes the ICJ has held that “[a]s a general rule it is for the party which alleges a fact in support of its claims to prove the existence of that fact” (ICJ, 2010).” (Greiman, 2021, p. 105)

“Importantly, the United States has not taken a standardized approach to attribution—either in the timing of attribution, the mode, the type, or the extent of evidence supporting the attribution, the confidence level, or whether attribution is followed by other punitive measures (Romanosky and Boudreaux, 2020). For example, the 2017 attribution of WannaCry and the 2018 attribution of NotPetya involved coordinated statements with international partners; however, in the Equifax cyber-attack, it was the private company that worked with the UK and Canadian regulators to determine appropriate next steps. Leveraging the capabilities of the private sector is a significant strategy that has been used by the United States and other countries.” (Greiman, 2021, p. 104)

“Researchers have proposed a due diligence framework or minimal standards for attribution of cyber-attacks (Chircop, 2018). A due diligence failure occurs when a state has knowledge of a cyber operation being carried out from within its territory, contrary to the rights of another, and fails to take reasonable measures to prevent it (Tallinn, Rule 6 at 42). Though due diligence is not clearly defined in the law it was reflected by the International Court of Justice (ICJ) in its Corfu Channel Judgment: “It is every State’s obligation not to allow knowingly its territory to be used for acts contrary to the rights of other states (Corfu, 1949) and has been set forth as an obligation of States in the pronouncements of the International Law Association (ILA, 2014). With the rise of cyber-attacks globally and no end in sight, international cyber security law is at a critical juncture. The failure of states to engage in the development and applications of international law has left a power vacuum allowing for the emergence of non-state norm-making initiatives (Mačák, 2017). As suggested here there is an opportunity now to employ the many initiatives and proposals for the development of standards and norms and to engage the international community in attribution norm and standards building practices.” (Greiman, 2021, p. 107)

metadata.title: The Politics and Practice of Cyber Attribution: A Global Legal Perspective
metadata.abstract: The conundrum of attribution has long been an issue in cyberspace where actors can secretly go about their business without fear of retaliation or retribution. Identifying the responsible actors for cyber- attacks is a monumental challenge though politics usually determines whether attributions are made public. When and how to accuse governments of a cyber-crime, cyber espionage or even an act of cyber war is a critical issue in reducing cyber conflicts and encouraging cyber cooperation. There is no international legal obligation to reveal the grounds on which attribution is based prior to taking appropriate action. States are likewise not obligated to provide evidence of attribution when responding to another state's cyber intrusions. Recognizing that customary international law has not developed a set of understandings or recognized state practice on what level of attribution is acceptable or necessary for establishing state responsibility for cyber actions this paper intends to address that gap. National governments, scholars, private industry, and think tanks have recently offered proposals and standards for the handling of attribution of state sponsored cyber-attacks. The focus of this article is to explore these proposals and standards from an international perspective through the analysis of national practice and international norms and regulations to determine how the international community might develop a system of law on attribution that would meet universal acceptance.
